FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org will continue to support TLS 1.0 and 1.1 until further notice
FeedItems.Summary: Last November, we shared our two-stage plan for deprecating TLS 1.0/1.1 on NuGet.org and actions you can take today to ensure your systems use TLS 1.2. In that post, we announced that NuGet.org would...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
co-authored by Scott Bommarito
At Microsoft, using the latest and secure encryption techniques is very important to us to ensure the security and privacy of our customers. TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1,...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating packages on nuget.org
FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

FeedItems.Title: Surfacing GitHub Usage for packages on NuGet.org

FeedItems.Title: NuGet Spring 2019 Roadmap
FeedItems.Summary: We published our last NuGet roadmap in June last year. Many of the features announced were major additions to NuGet and we have been hard at work to implement those over the last few months. In this...

FeedItems.Title: Enable repeatable package restores using a lock file
FeedItems.Summary: With PackageReference, NuGet always tries to produce the same closure of package dependencies if the input package reference list has not changed. However, there are a few scenarios where it may not...

FeedItems.Title: Lock down your dependencies using configurable trust policies

FeedItems.Title: Improved package debugging experience with the NuGet.org symbol server
FeedItems.Summary: Starting today, you can publish symbol packages to the NuGet.org symbol server. With NuGet.org as a single service provider for libraries and symbols, package authors and consumers will have a...

FeedItems.Title: Introducing Source Code Link for NuGet packages

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add build hook to AccountDeleter and GitHubVulnerabilities2Db" (#7973) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Stats page - NuGet Client Usage shows "1B" for multiple ticks" (#7972) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

NuGet Client Usage shows "1B" for multiple ticks on the Y axis. This is not very helpful.

### To Reproduce

1. Go to https://www.nuget.org/stats
2. Look at the chart under "NuGet Client Usage (Last 6 Weeks)"

### Expected behavior

It should show something like "1.21B", "1.39B" etc. 

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/80640957-ff94a000-8a18-11ea-8ddb-d97cf72d0d4b.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Improved link functionality for nuget.org" (#7942) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

Support for packages/{id}/latest, packages/{id}/latest/prerelease and packages/{id}/latest/prerelease/{tagName}

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7835

This PR fixes #7835

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Prepare to better support backward compatibility scenarios" (#9498) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This issue was discussed as part of CPVM delivery. However the problem can happen any time a new feature is added that old clients do not know how to deal with. Can a version based mechanism be used for this purpose?

In CPVM case, once a project is opt in CPVM its Version attributes are removed. Old clients will emit an warning in such cases but they will not fail.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[CPVM backcompat] Patch older tools to warn, error when a project is opt in cpvm" (#9497) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Once a project is opt in CPVM its Version attributes are removed. Old clients will emit an warning in such cases.

This issue is to track any work needed to patch old version of tools like nuget.exe, VS to error/warn when a file is opted in cpvm.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[CPVM backcompat] Enhance the warning NU1602 documentation." (#9496) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Once a project is opt in CPVM its Version attributes are removed. Old clients will emit an warning in such cases. 

Enhance the NU1602 documentation with reference to this scenario.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "net5.0 tfm support" (#9089) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "[Centrally managing NuGet packages and versions] Integrate PackageVersion information for non-sdk style projects in VS restore " (#9236) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
For non sdk style scenarios the project system data comes from a different pipeline. Integrate PackageVersion information to support restore for projects that are opt-in CPVM.

Related with https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8752

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enable test GetCertificateChain_WithUntrustedRoot_Throws on Mac and fix it " (#9495) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The test `GetCertificateChain_WithUntrustedRoot_Throws` is enabled on Mac in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3275
But the assertion didn't check for MacOS. So we should change the assertion to check the results on Mac and fix it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Does NuGet work with .net core?" (#9494) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

I have created a few simple .net core apps recently. I have just started to use on a bigger project and NuGet just doesn't seem to work.
It *installs* the package but no files are downloaded. This has happened for Typescript and Knockoutjs to name 2.
Should we be abandoning NuGet for other package managers?

Thanks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Running dotnet nuget push on Ubuntu randomly fails" (#9493) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Error:
```
Run dotnet nuget push *.nupkg --skip-duplicate --source GPR
warn : No API Key was provided and no API Key could be found for 'https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos'. To save an API Key for a source use the 'setApiKey' command.
Pushing yaos.OpenAPI.Diff.1.1.2-alpha.30.nupkg to 'https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos'...
  PUT https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos/
An error was encountered when fetching 'PUT https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos/'. The request will now be retried.
An error occurred while sending the request.
  The response ended prematurely.
  PUT https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos/
An error was encountered when fetching 'PUT https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos/'. The request will now be retried.
An error occurred while sending the request.
  The response ended prematurely.
  PUT https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos/
error: An error occurred while sending the request.
error:   The response ended prematurely.
```

dotnet --version 3.1.201
dotnet nuget --version 5.5.0.4
OS version: ubuntu-latest

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
Running the following action:
```
name: Publish pre-release

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - master
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - master

jobs:
  publish-lib:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    name: Publish OpenAPI Diff Action tool to nuget
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0 # avoid shallow clone so nbgv can do its work.
      - name: Setup nbgv
        uses: aarnott/nbgv@v0.3
      - name: Create the package
        run: dotnet pack --configuration Release
      - name: Add GPR Source
        run: dotnet nuget add source https://nuget.pkg.github.com/yaos/index.json --name GPR --username fabich --password ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }} --store-password-in-clear-text
      - name: Publish the package
        run: dotnet nuget push *.nupkg --skip-duplicate --source GPR
        working-directory: ./src/yaos.OpenAPI.Diff/nupkg
```

There is a similar issue #8580 that has been closed but I don't think that the suggested workaround works.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet Restore from private feed: The underlying connection was closed: An unexpected error occurred on a send." (#9492) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used : Tried all of them: 
* VS 2019 UI | 16.5.4
* dotnet.exe |
* Package manager console 5.5.0.6473
* NuGet.exe version 5.5.1.6542

OS version : Version 10.0.18363.778

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:
Worked until 5 days ago.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

I am trying to restore the packages on my Windows 10 Surface book (through all the above: VS, Nuget.exe dotnet restore, Package Manger Console) and all attempts to restore from the private feeds fail with the message in the Verbose Log section:
The packages exist on the feed, I have verified through the VSO UI package search, and  *I can restore on another computer where I am logged in with the same AAD credentials*.

My credentials (ADO PAT Tokens) are not expired. Below you can find the logs of running the credentials manager. I have also tried generating new PAT tokens through the web UI and using a username and password as authing mechanism - authentication seems to succeed despite an initial 401. 

I don't have any credentials for it in the Windows Credentials Manager. 
I have capture the net trace of the request, and all requests are using TLS 1.2. 
Some web searches for the error message that I get, take to TLS 1.2 posts.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show Preview Window setting - minor refactor / redesign" (#9491) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Consider whether we should be using the Registry to persist the "Show preview window" setting in the PMUI.  This isn't an ideal use of the Registry.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80558448-6cbc1d00-89a8-11ea-938b-446e0878aa6e.png)

Investigate whether we can move this setting to the VS Settings API ([current Setting logic](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/Xamls/PreviewWindow.xaml.cs#L89)).

A possible reason for using Registry may have been how our UI automated testing interacted with it, so that should be evaluated first to understand test changes that will be needed.

The design of this option being on 2 dialogs, and not kept in sync, was captured in this bug https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7901.

My suggestion is:
1. VS Setting persists the "default" value for previewing.
2. PMUI allows you to change that setting in a given Window. (eg, "I usually don't care, but this time I want to check the "preview" because I expect this package to make changes I'm worried about." ... or vice versa)
3. Registry is not involved at all.

//cc: @anangaur @chgill-MSFT

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Manager Settings Help Button (?) in VS2019 opens outdated VS2015 specific Docs" (#9490) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Visual Studio 2019 NuGet Settings dialog in `Tools ->NuGet Package Manager -> Package Manager Settings` has a Help Button (?) which opens the Docs page specific for vs2015. 

Selecting "?" in the top right....
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80553601-72aa0200-8998-11ea-8551-7ffd94f4f7b8.png)

.....opens this [Docs Page](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/adding-references-using-nuget-versus-an-extension-sdk?f1url=https%3A%2F%2Fmsdn.microsoft.com%2Fquery%2Fdev16.query%3FappId%3DDev16IDEF1%26l%3DEN-US%26k%3Dk(VS.ToolsOptionsPages.NuGet_Package_Manager.General)%26rd%3Dtrue&view=vs-2015) (with &view=vs-2015 in query string).

Note: I'm also not sure this is the best docs page as it's very generic info, and also even says it is specific to VS2015. Part of this work may be figuring out if we have a better doc to show and if not, addressing that (or in a separate docs issue).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80553701-cddbf480-8998-11ea-9730-e3cb4e6636e7.png)

NuGet product used VSUI
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 16.x

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org â€“ Stage 1" (#42) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## NuGet.org will temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 on February 26, 2020

We plan to temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 across 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each, to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. If you discover that you are impacted and cannot identify a workaround, please open an issue on the NuGet Gallery GitHub repo.

Read this blog post to learn more and to identify the test slot time in your time zone - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/deprecating-tls-1-0-and-1-1-on-nuget-org-stage-1/
